attributes.title: Political Letter Writing in the National Citizen Service

q1.value: Political Letter Writing in the National Citizen Service

q5.value: The National Citizen Service Trust for funding the research and supporting logistics, The Challenge Network for delivering the intervention and collecting the data, My doctoral supervisors: Professor Peter John, Dr Lucy Barnes and Dr Michael Sanders

q8.value: Registration prior to realization of outcomes

q15.value: This research aims to answer the following question: What is the effect on the individual of a practical experience of political participation during service learning, and how is this effect produced? Young people participate in formal political activities – voting, contacting politicians, petitioning and protest – in relatively low numbers (Ipsos MORI 2015 & 2017). But they are not disengaged from social and environmental issues or from civic life. When it comes to non-political civic participation, 16 to 25-year olds are the most active age group in the UK (Cabinet Office 2016). It has been suggested that this pattern of behaviour represents a generational shift in preferences away from formal political participation and towards modes of participation such as non-political community service (Kahne et al. 2013, p.420). In the US, Richard Dalton observes a normative transition away from the ‘duty-based citizen’ of the post-war and baby boomer generations towards the ‘engaged citizen’ of Generation X and the Millennials (Dalton 2016, pp.5-6). This shift is a normative concern for those who believe in the importance of equal participation in formal politics, and a policy concern for those democracies in which political participation between age groups is unequal. But it also raises theoretical questions, for which we do not have complete answers; namely, ‘What are the reasons for this for this inequality in participation?’ and, ‘What are the key mechanisms that influence youth participation?’. This research aims to make a contribution to these theoretical concerns by conducting an empirical study in a policy-relevant context in the UK. Many democratic governments have in recent decades implemented programmes of ‘service learning’ that aim to increase the level of civic engagement amongst young people. In the UK, the government recently committed c.£1 billion to the National Citizen Service (NCS); its own programme of service learning in which c.50% of UK school-leavers are expected to participate per year by 2020.

q16.value: H1.1: Political mastery experiences increase participants’ political efficacy. H1.2: As a result, political mastery experiences increase participants’ likelihood of future political participation. H2.1: Political mastery experiences that fail to demonstrate system responsiveness increase participants’ internal political efficacy (IPE) but not their external political efficacy (EPE). H2.2: As a result, political mastery experiences that fail to demonstrate system responsiveness increase the likelihood of future extra-system participation, but have no effect on the likelihood of future within-system participation. H2.3: Political mastery experiences that do demonstrate system responsiveness increase participants’ IPE and their EPE. H2.4: As a result, political mastery experiences that do demonstrate system responsiveness increase the likelihood of future participation in all forms of within-system political participation, but have no effect on the likelihood of future extra-system participation. H3.1: Political mastery experiences have a larger positive effect on political efficacy and likelihood of future political participation for participants from low-SES backgrounds.

q17.value: To test these hypotheses, a two-arm clustered randomised controlled trial will be implemented to test the effects of an intervention - a political letter writing activity for participants of the UK’s National Citizen Service (NCS) - designed to address the hypotheses. The activity has three stages to it: • Stage 1: The team of NCS participants selects an issue that they would like to write to a politician about. • Stage 2: The team’s Mentor runs a political letter writing workshop with the team to draft a letter. • Stage 3: A representative (or representatives) from the team writes up and sends the letter using www.writetothem.com. These representatives will be volunteers from the team who have access to the internet. In some cases, all members of the team may participate in this stage, in others, only a subset will participate. The control group will participate in the ‘business as usual’ version of the NCS programme. As a service learning experience NCS does, in itself, include a range of mastery experiences that are expected to increase participants’ self-efficacy in a range of corresponding domains, including that of non-political civic participation. Observing an effect from the intervention depends upon the assumption that it will have an effect on the primary outcome, over and above any effect caused by the business as usual programme. A post-intervention survey instrument will be used to assess participants’ intention to participate in political activities in the future and their political efficacy. See attached Trial Protocol for more details.

q25.value: First ethics application approved: 22/03/2018. Amendments to ethics application approved: 24/07/2018.

q27.value: The Challenge Network (a provider of the National Citizen Service)

attributes.title: Are Political Elites Out-of-Touch? Experimental Evidence From the 2018 Midterm Elections

q1.value: Are Political Elites Out-of-Touch? Experimental Evidence From the 2018 Midterm Elections

q9.value: Registration prior to completion of data collection (complete in September 2018). However, I note that I have had access to the data collected thus far, and have performed preliminary analysis to ensure that the survey is functioning properly.

q15.value: The purpose of this study is to establish: (1) Whether political elites have accurate perceptions of social conditions in the United States and (2) Whether political elites’ misperceptions of social conditions cause them to oppose redistributive social policies.

q16.value: The primary hypothesis is that correcting elites’ misperceptions of social conditions will lead them to become more supportive of redistributive social policies.

q17.value: This hypothesis will be tested with a survey experiment conducted on candidates in the 2018 primary elections. Respondents randomly assigned to a treatment condition will be provided with accurate information about social problem, while respondents randomly assigned to a control condition will receive no such information. Afterword, the two groups’ views on relevant social policies will be compared. I will make these comparisons both for the respondents as a group, and for Democratic and Republic respondents’ separately.

q19.value: The survey aims to recruit as many candidates in the 2018 midterm elections as possible. Based on current response rates, the final response rate will likely be larger than N = 1,000.

attributes.title: How Do International Audiences Respond to Ratification of International Human Rights Agreements? A Survey Experiment on UK Residents

q1.value: How Do International Audiences Respond to Ratification of International Human Rights Agreements? A Survey Experiment on UK Residents

q5.value: The author acknowledges research funding from the School of Politics and International Relations, The Australian National University.

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q16.value: H1. As compared to the control group, respondents who receive Article #2 (ratification vignette) and have low knowledge of Zimbabwe’s politics, society, and human rights will rate the President of Zimbabwe more favorably, will believe torture to be less likely and less acceptable, will believe Zimbabwe to be more respected by the international community, and will believe that the Zimbabwean government cares more about its citizens. H2. As knowledge of Zimbabwe increases, the treatment will be less ‘effective,’ i.e., the differences between the treatment and control groups will diminish. H3. Among respondents with high knowledge of Zimbabwe, the treatment will not have beneficial impacts on the outcomes outlined in H1. Based on some previous research, a ‘backlash’ effect is possible, whereby high-knowledge respondents have less favorable attitudes than do high-knowledge respondents in the control group. Other hypotheses are delineated in the pre-analysis plan.

q17.value: Average treatment effects, mediation analysis. If necessary, I will use propensity score matching – but only if the treatment and control groups are unbalanced

attributes.title: Can Information on Egalitarian Public Service Delivery Distribution Reduce Beliefs and Attitudes of Ethno-partisan Favoritism?

q1.value: Can Information on Egalitarian Public Service Delivery Distribution Reduce Beliefs and Attitudes of Ethno-partisan Favoritism?

q5.value: We thank Nicole Audette and our enumeration team led by Walter Ludenyo.

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher analysis of outcome data

q15.value: This project examines beliefs about ethno-partisan favoritism in Kenya and investigates whether an information treatment providing evidence of the incumbent’s egalitarian allocation of electricity affects individuals’ beliefs and attitudes about future favoritism. We examine these questions through a survey of nearly 2,000 Kikuyus and Luos in Nairobi and rural areas conducted prior to the 2017 elections. In our sample, 91% of Kikuyus are partisan to the incumbent Jubilee, 4% NASA (the opposition), and 6% no response, while 87% of Luos are partisan to NASA, 6% to Jubilee, and 8% no response. We employ a survey experiment in which a randomly-assigned portion of respondents receive information from an official government source (Kenya Power) regarding the distribution of electricity by the incumbent Jubilee party as part of the “Last Mile” electricity connectivity project. We use data on electrification for this treatment both because electricity is a highly valued, government-provided service and because the data on electrification offer evidence of an inclusive strategy by the incumbent government. The map shows a rather equitable distribution of electrification under Jubilee to different parts of Kenya where different ethno-partisan groups are concentrated, and is accompanied by a verbal narration as such from the enumerator.  Standard accounts of ethnic politics propose that in multiethnic settings voters expect political leaders to favor their own ethnic communities rather than distributing government-controlled resources broadly across the country, leading parties to nest certain ethnic groups (e.g., Ekeh 1975; Bates 1983; Horowitz 1985; Posner 2005; Chandra 2004). Theories of political behavior presume that expectations of ethno-partisan favoritism lead to a preference for co-ethnic candidates and can, under some conditions, result in ethnic bloc voting and fears of neglect if one’s ethno-partisan group is not in power (Posner 2005; Chandra 2004; Ferree 2011). Beliefs about ethnic favoritism may also contribute to ethnic grievances that fuel conflict (Gurr 1993; Wimmer, Cederman and Min 2009; Cederman, Gleditsch and Buhaug 2013), especially leading to ethno-partisan tensions around elections (Michelitch 2015).  Yet, these beliefs, and subsequent tensions and fears, are generated in an environment in which citizens have very little information about how incumbent governments actually distribute resources. Parties often attempt to claim to distribute widely while campaigning to try to woo voters outside their core supporters and supporting favoritism is seen as taboo or “tribalist” or anti modern democracy (Horowitz 2018). Often, one hears anecdotally that one’s own party does not engage in favoritism, only the opposing party, perhaps a function of rumors or cognitive incentives to improve group self-image. Studies attempting to determine whether there is indeed ethno-partisan favoritism in public service delivery, however, show mixed results across countries, sectors, and over time (e.g., Kramon and Posner 2013). In Kenya, for example, it appears that historically water, health, and electricity are not distributed to favor coethnics, while education appears to be favoritistic. In our own examination of electricity data, the focus of this study, we find an egalitarian distribution by the incumbent government during the term at conclusion. Our question is whether receiving information showing that the incumbent government has distributed a public good equitably will prompt change in beliefs about whether the government will distribute the good equitably or favoritistically if elected for another term. Second, we question whether receiving such information will affect one’s own desire to distribute equitably or favoritistically to one’s own ethno-partisan group. Whether individuals change their beliefs about the incumbent’s disposition to favor its own ethno-partisan group may follow a simple belief updating model. Some individuals may already believe the incumbent is egalitarian, and then new information would not produce an effect. Others may view the incumbent as favoritistic, and the information will prompt a change in beliefs that the incumbent is egalitarian.  Alternatively, citizens may engage in motivated reasoning. The motivated reasoning framework proposes that cognitive biases lead individuals to arrive at beliefs that are consistent with one’s preferred state of the world and reinforce prior beliefs (Taber and Lodge 2006, Kunda 1990). Thus, individuals that already believe the incumbent is egalitarian will receive new information that would confirm their belief, leaving it unchanged. Individuals that already believe the incumbent is favoritistic will reject new information that would oppose their belief, leaving it unchanged or doubling-down on their prior beliefs in line with a “backlash” model (e.g., Nyhan and Reifler 2010). Rather than motivated reasoning conforming to one’s own prior beliefs, motivated reasoning has also been suggested to occur regarding information that reflects poorly or well on one’s group, ethnic or partisan (Carlson 2016, Posner 2004, Horowitz 2012, Ferree 2011, Adida et al 2018). That is, when individuals find out information that reflects negatively on their group, they reject it, while they accept positive information about their group. However, for information regarding opposing groups, they accept negative information and reject positive information. This selective acceptance and rejection of information may be related to social identity theory in which individuals seek to maintain a positive self-image of their group membership.  Of course, there could be a link between beliefs about incumbent favoritism (versus egalitarianism) and one’s ethno-partisan affiliation. Ethno-partisan affiliation may drive beliefs in incumbent favoritism: ethnopartisans of the opposition may believe in incumbent favoritism, while ethnopartisans of the incumbent may believe in incumbent egalitarianism. Indeed, in eliciting Kikuyus (nearly all Jubilee-incumbent supporters) and Luos (nearly all NASA opposition supporters) beliefs about past favoritism, Kikuyus nearly all say that Jubilee was egalitarian, while Luos are split in their beliefs. We also measure implicit associations with the parties using Implicit Association Tests (IATs), arguably a more innate measure, as to whether citizens associate each party with favoritism or egalitarianism, and find variation among both Luos and Kikuyus.  We also explore several moderators. If someone has witnessed delivery of public services as a member of the ethno-partisan opposition in their area, they may be more willing to update beliefs about the government’s future behavior in response to the treatment, given that their own personal experience will be consistent with the information provided by the treatment. Second, we examine whether the treatment effect is moderated by the rural/urban divide, age, or the socioeconomic status divide, given the urbanites, young people, and the wealthy may have more flexible beliefs to update in response to information. Finally, we examine whether treatment effects are conditional on how favoritistic one believes historical administrations have been - it could be that individuals who believe in a long line of favoritism by past governments will have such firmly rooted beliefs that they will not update based on receiving a single piece of information. As for one’s own decision about how one would distribute electricity if one were in power, we propose that receiving information about an egalitarian distribution by the incumbent would increase the desire to distribute equitably oneself. There may be many mechanisms behind why this effect might occur. First, without the information treatment, Kikuyus may be mixed in terms of how personally egotropic or sociotropic they would distribute a public good such as electricity. However, Kikuyus receiving an information treatment may take a partisan cue from their party and be more likely to distribute equitably. A substantial literature details how individuals tend to follow even subtle partisan cues from co-partisan leaders in supporting policy (e.g., Kam 2005), even in newer democracies (e.g., Brader & Tucker 2009). Second, Luos may also be mixed in terms of how egotropic or sociotropic they would distribute public goods such as electricity. Without the information about Jubilee’s egalitarianism, Luos may be more likely to justify enriching Luos because of the idea that Luos have been neglected and out of government since independence. However, receiving information that the opposing Jubilee incumbent party has taken the noble route of egalitarianism may increase the sense that one should also take the noble route so as not to sink below them to engage in a pejorative behavior of favoritism (“tribalism”).  However, this effect may be moderated by not having received electricity in one’s area, lower SES, rural status, and beliefs in a long-term history of incumbent favoritism since independence. These traits may override the effect of the map information because such respondents may desire development among themselves in their locality or their group to a larger degree. We are also interested in ancillary outcomes such as worries or fears about redistribution when one’s group is out of government, as well as beliefs about how the opposition party might redistribute public services.

q16.value: The treatment is a map showing a wide national spread of electrification improvements by the incumbent government, data from the Kenya Power official sources. We have primary hypotheses (with proposed moderators), as well as secondary hypotheses (with proposed moderators), and ancillary exploratory interests.  Main Hypotheses: (1)    The treatment will affect beliefs that if Jubilee wins the 2017 election, all ethnic groups will benefit (“egalitarian distribution”) (rather than Jubilee will favor “some” ethnic groups (“ethno-partisan favoritism”)) (Q293) according to the following hypothesis table. The moderator regarding prior beliefs will be operationalized in 2 ways: (a) an explicit question about Jubilee’s prior favoritism in redistribution of electricity (Q286/Q287) and (b) an IAT test of respondent’s implicit association of Jubilee with favoritism versus egalitarianism (randomly assigned half sample only).  Hypothesis Table: Prior Belief: Egalitarian Distribution; Updating Model: No effect; Motivated Reasoning Model: No effect or increase belief in future egalitarianism Prior Belief: Favoritism to Incumbent’s Ethno-partisans; Updating Model: Increase belief in incumbent party’s future egalitarian distribution; Motivated Reasoning Model: No effect or decrease belief in future egalitarianism (backlash) (2)    The treatment increases the probability an individual targets electricity improvements in an egalitarian (rather than ethno-partisan favoritistic way) if they were president (Q291). Moderators of Main effects: (a)    The treatment will have a larger effect among those whose community has been electrified by the incumbent government (Q130/131/132/133/134/135) (b)    The treatment will have a larger effect among higher SES (Q124-126), urban  (measurements of urban and ruralness from battery of questions Q304-314 for urbanites and Q315-327 for rural dwellers), and younger age (from eligibility screen for survey participation “QAGE”). (c)    The treatment will have a larger effect among those with less belief in a long-term history of past favoritism. We will construct an index based on  questions regarding many types of public goods (Q276-287). Secondary Hypotheses: general worry/fear about Jubilee’s redistribution on development: (1)    More equitable distribution of general development spending (degree to which individuals believe Jubilee will spend in Jubilee strongholds (Q298) minus an average of degree to which individuals believe Jubliee will spend in swing (Q299) or opposition strongholds (Q300). (2)    (Luos only) less worry that Luos will get less development if they don’t have group members in the ruling coalition (Q294). (3)    (Luos only) stronger beliefs that if Jubilee wins it will represent the interests of Luos (Q296). Ancillary Exploratory Investigations: if spillover to beliefs about Opposition Party: (1)    Increases the probability that individuals believe if NASA (the opposition) wins the 2017 election, all ethnic groups will benefit (rather than NASA will favor “some” ethnic groups) (Q293).  (2)    More equitable distribution of general development spending (degree to which individuals believe NASA will spend in NASA strongholds (Q301) minus an average of degree to which individuals believe NASA will spend in swing (Q302) or opposition strongholds (Q303). (3)     (Kikuyus only) less worry that Kikuyus will get less development if they don’t have group members in the ruling coalition (Q294). (4)    (Kikuyus only) beliefs that NASA will represent the interests of one’s ethnic group if it wins (Q295). In these investigations, we will limit the sample to Kikuyu-Jubilee and Luo-NASA supporters, which in our sample, 91% of Kikuyus are partisan to the incumbent Jubilee, 4% NASA (the opposition), and 6% no response, while 87% of Luos are partisan to NASA, 6% to Jubilee, and 8% no response in the strictest definition of someone stating partisan support. We can include leaners as well in another operationalization. Ethnic group is measured by a direct question (Q127) and partisan affiliation is measured by Q196 in a strict way and Q189-190 for more expansive or different way.

q17.value: If the dependent variable is binary, we will use logistic regression. If the dependent variable is ordered, we will use ordinary least squares regression. We will use robust standard errors to ward against heteroscedasticity. To examine moderators, we will use the empirical models and hypothesis testing described in Franzese, Robert J., and Cindy Kam. Modeling and interpreting interactive hypotheses in regression analysis. University of Michigan Press, 2009.

q19.value: about 1,925 but some data only available on subsamples (e.g., IAT data, special questions for rural versus urban samples)

q25.value: approved 5/8/2017 by VU, approved 5/15/2017 by Dartmouth

Ethno-partisan affiliation may drive beliefs in incumbent favoritism: ethnopartisans of the opposition may believe in incumbent favoritism, while ethnopartisans of the incumbent may believe in incumbent egalitarianism. Indeed, in eliciting Kikuyus (nearly all Jubilee-incumbent supporters) and Luos (nearly all NASA opposition supporters) beliefs about past favoritism, Kikuyus nearly all say that Jubilee was egalitarian, while Luos are split in their beliefs. We also measure implicit associations with the parties using Implicit Association Tests (IATs), arguably a more innate measure, as to whether citizens associate each party with favoritism or egalitarianism, and find variation among both Luos and Kikuyus.  We also explore several moderators. If someone has witnessed delivery of public services as a member of the ethno-partisan opposition in their area, they may be more willing to update beliefs about the government’s future behavior in response to the treatment, given that their own personal experience will be consistent with the information provided by the treatment. Second, we examine whether the treatment effect is moderated by the rural/urban divide, age, or the socioeconomic status divide, given the urbanites, young people, and the wealthy may have more flexible beliefs to update in response to information. Finally, we examine whether treatment effects are conditional on how favoritistic one believes historical administrations have been - it could be that individuals who believe in a long line of favoritism by past governments will have such firmly rooted beliefs that they will not update based on receiving a single piece of information. As for one’s own decision about how one would distribute electricity if one were in power, we propose that receiving information about an egalitarian distribution by the incumbent would increase the desire to distribute equitably oneself. There may be many mechanisms behind why this effect might occur. First, without the information treatment, Kikuyus may be mixed in terms of how personally egotropic or sociotropic they would distribute a public good such as electricity. However, Kikuyus receiving an information treatment may take a partisan cue from their party and be more likely to distribute equitably. A substantial literature details how individuals tend to follow even subtle partisan cues from co-partisan leaders in supporting policy (e.g., Kam 2005), even in newer democracies (e.g., Brader & Tucker 2009). Second, Luos may also be mixed in terms of how egotropic or sociotropic they would distribute public goods such as electricity. Without the information about Jubilee’s egalitarianism, Luos may be more likely to justify enriching Luos because of the idea that Luos have been neglected and out of government since independence. However, receiving information that the opposing Jubilee incumbent party has taken the noble route of egalitarianism may increase the sense that one should also take the noble route so as not to sink below them to engage in a pejorative behavior of favoritism (“tribalism”).  However, this effect may be moderated by not having received electricity in one’s area, lower SES, rural status, and beliefs in a long-term history of incumbent favoritism since independence. These traits may override the effect of the map information because such respondents may desire development among themselves in their locality or their group to a larger degree. We are also interested in ancillary outcomes such as worries or fears about redistribution when one’s group is out of government, as well as beliefs about how the opposition party might redistribute public services.
registration_responses.q16: The treatment is a map showing a wide national spread of electrification improvements by the incumbent government, data from the Kenya Power official sources. We have primary hypotheses (with proposed moderators), as well as secondary hypotheses (with proposed moderators), and ancillary exploratory interests.  Main Hypotheses: (1)    The treatment will affect beliefs that if Jubilee wins the 2017 election, all ethnic groups will benefit (“egalitarian distribution”) (rather than Jubilee will favor “some” ethnic groups (“ethno-partisan favoritism”)) (Q293) according to the following hypothesis table. The moderator regarding prior beliefs will be operationalized in 2 ways: (a) an explicit question about Jubilee’s prior favoritism in redistribution of electricity (Q286/Q287) and (b) an IAT test of respondent’s implicit association of Jubilee with favoritism versus egalitarianism (randomly assigned half sample only).  Hypothesis Table: Prior Belief: Egalitarian Distribution; Updating Model: No effect; Motivated Reasoning Model: No effect or increase belief in future egalitarianism Prior Belief: Favoritism to Incumbent’s Ethno-partisans; Updating Model: Increase belief in incumbent party’s future egalitarian distribution; Motivated Reasoning Model: No effect or decrease belief in future egalitarianism (backlash) (2)    The treatment increases the probability an individual targets electricity improvements in an egalitarian (rather than ethno-partisan favoritistic way) if they were president (Q291). Moderators of Main effects: (a)    The treatment will have a larger effect among those whose community has been electrified by the incumbent government (Q130/131/132/133/134/135) (b)    The treatment will have a larger effect among higher SES (Q124-126), urban  (measurements of urban and ruralness from battery of questions Q304-314 for urbanites and Q315-327 for rural dwellers), and younger age (from eligibility screen for survey participation “QAGE”). (c)    The treatment will have a larger effect among those with less belief in a long-term history of past favoritism. We will construct an index based on  questions regarding many types of public goods (Q276-287). Secondary Hypotheses: general worry/fear about Jubilee’s redistribution on development: (1)    More equitable distribution of general development spending (degree to which individuals believe Jubilee will spend in Jubilee strongholds (Q298) minus an average of degree to which individuals believe Jubliee will spend in swing (Q299) or opposition strongholds (Q300). (2)    (Luos only) less worry that Luos will get less development if they don’t have group members in the ruling coalition (Q294). (3)    (Luos only) stronger beliefs that if Jubilee wins it will represent the interests of Luos (Q296). Ancillary Exploratory Investigations: if spillover to beliefs about Opposition Party: (1)    Increases the probability that individuals believe if NASA (the opposition) wins the 2017 election, all ethnic groups will benefit (rather than NASA will favor “some” ethnic groups) (Q293).  (2)    More equitable distribution of general development spending (degree to which individuals believe NASA will spend in NASA strongholds (Q301) minus an average of degree to which individuals believe NASA will spend in swing (Q302) or opposition strongholds (Q303). (3)     (Kikuyus only) less worry that Kikuyus will get less development if they don’t have group members in the ruling coalition (Q294). (4)    (Kikuyus only) beliefs that NASA will represent the interests of one’s ethnic group if it wins (Q295). In these investigations, we will limit the sample to Kikuyu-Jubilee and Luo-NASA supporters, which in our sample, 91% of Kikuyus are partisan to the incumbent Jubilee, 4% NASA (the opposition), and 6% no response, while 87% of Luos are partisan to NASA, 6% to Jubilee, and 8% no response in the strictest definition of someone stating partisan support. We can include leaners as well in another operationalization. Ethnic group is measured by a direct question (Q127) and partisan affiliation is measured by Q196 in a strict way and Q189-190 for more expansive or different way.
registration_responses.q17: If the dependent variable is binary, we will use logistic regression. If the dependent variable is ordered, we will use ordinary least squares regression. We will use robust standard errors to ward against heteroscedasticity. To examine moderators, we will use the empirical models and hypothesis testing described in Franzese, Robert J., and Cindy Kam. Modeling and interpreting interactive hypotheses in regression analysis. University of Michigan Press, 2009.
registration_responses.q19: about 1,925 but some data only available on subsamples (e.g., IAT data, special questions for rural versus urban samples)
registration_responses.q25: approved 5/8/2017 by VU, approved 5/15/2017 by Dartmouth

attributes.title: Partisan Cuing on Public Service Delivery? Evidence from an Electoral Authoritarian Regime

q1.value: Partisan Cuing on Public Service Delivery? Evidence from an Electoral Authoritarian Regime

q5.value: Michelitch acknowledges the Andrew Carnegie Fellowship’s support, a wonderful partnership with Uganda’s Advocates Coalition for Development and the Environment (ACODE), and Guy Grossman as part of the original research team in charge of the larger research project. Thank you to the Vanderbilt RIPS lab for comments.

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher analysis of outcome data

q15.value: Partisanship is one of the most relevant determinants of political behavior in both developed and developing democracies (Huddy and Bankert 2017, Brader and Tucker 2018, Slothuus 2016). In the American context, where parties are stable, long-lived and ideologically distinct, there is strong experimental evidence that elite party cues serve as a form of heuristics capable of influencing copartisan citizens’ attitudes towards policy, candidate evaluations, political values, and even perceptions of objective indicators (Bartels 2002, Boudreau and Mackenzie 2014, Bullock 2011, Cohen 2003, Druckman et al. 2013, Nicholson 2012, Kam 2005, Goren et al. 2009, Slothuus and de Vreese 2010). Party cues were also shown to be influential in the more complex context of stable multiparty democracies (Brader and Tucker 2012, 2018, Brader et al. 2013, Bankert et al. 2017). However, we know little about the effect of partisan cuing where multiparty competition has been recently introduced. In this study we ask: what effect do party cues have on citizens evaluation of public goods provision in dominant party systems where multiparty competition has been recently introduced? Specifically, we examine the effect of party cues regarding universal primary education (UPE) in Uganda, where the NRM has ruled at the national level since 1986 and where multiparty competition has been allowed since 2006. Public service delivery is especially important in Uganda and more widely in the Global South, given the centrality of government-provided services for human development and economic growth in contexts of high poverty. When partisan cuing takes place, it could challenge citizens’ ability to evaluate public service delivery and hold government properly accountable. Across sub-Saharan Africa, the introduction of UPE has been rapid but very controversial, given that it expands access to education for more citizens, but often dilutes its quality due to rapid expansions of the student body without commensurate investments in school infrastructure and staff (Harding & Stasavage 2013). In Uganda, primary school enrollment more than doubled after UPE was implemented in 1997. However, government expenditure on primary education as a share of GDP has consistently declined since 2000, leading to overcrowded classrooms, limited availability of textbooks and other school materials, and a high pupil-to-teacher ratio (Duclos et al., 2013). There are good reasons to think that assessing party cues’ effect is premature in such contexts. Party identification is usually seen either in terms of a social identity that forms during early adult socialization, remains relatively unchanged over time, and depends on consistent differentiation between the in-group and out-groups (Green et al 2002), or a conscious choice based on prior party performance and the consistent match of a party’s policy preferences to those of individuals (Fiorina 1981, Franklin and Jackson 1983, Achen 1992). However, party systems in developing democracies that are unconsolidated can often be characterized by new and unstable political parties which have little or uncertain ideological distinction (Lupu 2013, Weghorst and Bernhard 2014, Bernhard & Karakoç 2011). Without long-term partisan identity building or party track records, one might question the existence of party cuing in systems where multiparty competition has been recently introduced. However, there is also good reason to believe that party cues could explicitly shape citizens’ attitudes towards public service delivery in Uganda, an electoral authoritarian regime. A range of scholarship supports the idea that partisanship can take hold quickly and operate similarly to partisanship in advanced democracies: mutually reinforcing political participation (Harding & Michelitch forthcoming, Lupu 2015, Brader and Tucker 2001, 2009), affecting discrimination on partisan lines (Michelitch 2015), and waning and waxing over the electoral cycle (Michelitch & Utych 2018). Indeed, in Uganda, party labels have been found to aid voters in identifying vote choice (Conroy-Krutz et al 2016), and bias retrospective performance views (Carlson 2016). Further, recent studies point to the idea that party cuing can have meaningful effects on citizens’ public opinion outside of advanced democracies, such as Brazil (Samuels and Zucco 2014), Pakistan (Siddiqui 2018), Russia (Brader & Tucker 2009), and UK/Poland/Hungary (Brader, Tucker, Duell 2013). This study expands on such previous work on party cuing, partisanship, and public opinion by examining party cuing in an electoral authoritarian regime without left-right ideological distinction between parties.

q16.value: Traditional Hypothesis: copartisans’ public opinion follows the lead of their party and moves away from other parties. H1: Positive (negative) cues increase (decrease) copartisans’/independents’ (non-copartisans’/independents’) satisfaction with UPE schools. “Stronger NRM Hypothesis”: Samuels & Zucco (2018) find that cues have larger effects from a “central party” in Brazil. Thus, cues could be stronger from the NRM, the ruling party, than from the opposition party (FDC). H2A: NRM cues are larger than FDC cues. “Stronger Opposition Hypothesis”: Brader, Tucker, and Duell (2013) find that cues from opposition parties are stronger because opposition parties can keep a party brand tighter and more certain, while the ruling parties can become a “catch all” party. The contexts that they examine, however are ones in which parties are ideologically distinct. H2B: FDC cues are larger than NRM cues. “Counterintuitive Cue Hypothesis”: Brader & Tucker 2009, Nicholson (2011) demonstrated that cues providing counterintuitive information that runs contrary to citizens’ beliefs about the position of the party are especially powerful. Since the UPE was introduced by the NRM, negative cues from NRM about UPE may be especially impactful. H3: NRM negative cues are the most powerful cues. Heterogeneous Effects at the Individual Level: • Effects will be smaller among: o parents who have children enrolled in UPE currently, given stronger existing information on performance (e.g., Boudreau and MacKenzie 2014). o those rating public schools at the extremes (very good/bad) (e.g., Boudreau and MacKenzie 2014) o those with higher education levels (e.g., Kam 2005) o those more politically aware (e.g., Kam 2005) Heterogeneous Effects at the Aggregate Level: • Exploration of effects by more or less mixed partisan district o Mixed partisan districts could lend legitimacy to both parties, while in NRM strongholds, the opposition may have little legitimacy, and cues could vary in strength, arguably in either direction.

q17.value: The survey experiment consists of reading randomly assigned real party Member of Parliament or party State Minister quotas about the status of UPE schools. There are four levels of treatment: one positive and one negative quota about UPE schools from the ruling party, NRM, and one positive and one negative quota from the main opposition party, the FDC. Descriptive statistics shows that the treatment was indeed randomly assigned. The exact wording for each treatment level can be seen on table 3: Treatment Levels W1 (NRM Positive) “Even though UPE has its own weaknesses, it has been hailed world-wide as a wonderful programme, a reflection of political commitment to education for all, and a role model of how the poorest countries of the world, such as Uganda, can eliminate widespread illiteracy and develop their human resources by provision of affordable education.” -NRM MP Alex Ndeezi, Enabling Education Network NGO Newsletter, 2000 W2 (NRM Negative) “State minister for higher education, Dr. John Muyingo, has said absenteeism of teachers and pupils especially in rural areas is crippling the... UPE programmes. He said, ‘...This genre of corruption in the primary education sector and teacher absenteeism has led to the delivery of poor quality primary education services.” -NRM State Minister for Higher Education, Dr. John Muyingo, New Vision, March 13 2012. W3 (Oppos. Positive) “Members of Parliament from both the ruling government and the opposition have applauded President Museveni for ordering a reform of the Universal Education Programme... The Woman MP Betty Aol Achan says... all political parties in Uganda support the UPE programme because it offers education to the less privileged in society...” -FDC MP Betty Aol Achan, Uganda Pulse, March 31 2010. W4 (Oppos. Negative) “We have a breakdown of public services like education. The introduction of UPE is another way of corruption in Uganda where by all the UPE products gets out from the UPE government schools without even knowing how to write their names.” -FDC MP Lucy Ajoko, Uganda News Picks, March 31, 2009. By including real quotes from party elites, we sought to increase the ecological validity of our experiment, as they provide more credible party cues. The immediate trade-off is the treatments are not identical with a few word changes and treatment effects must be considered a bundle of potential subtle cues within the treatment. Following the reading of the quotes, respondents will be asked to rate their satisfaction with UPE schools through a five-point likert scale: 117E Which of the following statements best represents how satisfied you are with UPE schools in your district? [Read answer options out loud.] 1. I am very dissatisfied with UPE schools. 2. I am dissatisfied with UPE schools. 3. I am neither satisfied nor dissatisfied with UPE schools. 4. I am satisfied with UPE schools. 5. I am very satisfied with UPE schools. The treatment levels will then be matched with our party identification variable. The variable will be recoded into a dummy variable classifying respondents as NRM and opposition party identifiers: 101 Please find the symbol of the party on the reference sheet that you feel the closest to. Then fill in the circle on your answer sheet with the SAME NUMBER as the number of the party you feel closest to on the answer sheet. For instance if you feel closest to DP, find the number of the DP symbol on the sheet, and then fill in the circle with the same number on your answer sheet. Finally, the survey experiment is embedded in an extensive baseline survey from a wider project on the effect of the dissemination of incumbent performance information on politicians’ accountability in Uganda. The survey experiment is performed at the end of the questionnaire. Prior to that, a battery of questions on education provision, including the UPE schools themselves, takes place at around the midpoint of the questionnaire. These questions should have propped respondents to organize their thoughts on UPE schools before getting to the experiment. Note that due to a technical glitch, there is no control group receiving no message. Thus, we compare treatments versus one another using OLS with district fixed effects. We first will assess ATEs, then treatment effects conditional on NRM, opposition, and no partisanship using a fully interactive model and/or splitting samples. To examine heterogeneous treatment effects, we will split samples to avoid interpreting many triple interactions of many valued covariates. (The authors added the section on 16 December 2019.) A “baseline” treatment is the positive NRM treatment - this is the dominant dialogue in the public sphere about UPE from the political elite. Thus, we will report the results relative to this as a “baseline” condition. A second way we will analyze the data is by examining difference in differences. We will assess whether the difference between NRM positive and NRM negative is significantly different from the difference between FDC positive and FDC negative. This analysis will allow us to understand whether NRM party cuing is stronger than FDC cuing, to assess H1, H2A and H2B. We will similarly analyze heterogeneous effects with this difference in differences approach.

q19.value: Data comes from a survey experiment with 6,123 respondents from 20 districts (part of a larger research project) from August-December 2012. We surveyed a sample of adults in every subcounty in the districts, selected using multi-stage random sampling.

q24.value: We received research permits from the Ugandan government (the Uganda National Council for Science and Technology (UNCST) --- SS 2817 and the president’s office) as well as IRB clearance for the research arm of IPA.

q25.value: The UNCST approved on July 16, 2012; IRB approval on 5/23/2012

attributes.title: Attitudes towards Taxation: Evidence from a Survey Experiment

q1.value: Attitudes towards Taxation: Evidence from a Survey Experiment

q8.value: Registration prior to realization of outcomes

q15.value: Under what conditions do citizens support a tax increase even though it decreases their disposable income? How can governments influence attitudes towards necessary taxation increase? Existing scholarship has emphasized government reform, taxpayer monitoring, penalty enforcement, social norms, ethics, and more. In this project, we investigate whether and which discursive strategies can influence tax preferences of citizens. We expect citizens to be generally more supportive of taxes when they are told that tax revenues are more likely to lead to direct, personal benefits, rather than collective gains.

q16.value: This project will examine under which conditions citizens are more likely to support taxes. Our main goal is to test whether citizens are more likely to support taxation increases when they are justified by reference to the following: 1. Nation - deficit: when citizens are informed that taxes will be able to reduce government deficits. 2. Nation - spending: when citizens are informed that taxes will enable the government to increase social spending. 3. Neighbor - emulation: when citizens are informed that Kuwait's neighbors have implemented the taxes. 4. Neighbor - security/competition: when citizens are informed that taxes allowed other countries to build stronger military. Overall, we expect that support for VAT will be higher after exposure to Nation conditions because under this context, taxes are more likely to directly benefit citizens. This will be especially true for the nation-spending condition under which citizens are more likely to receive direct benefits from higher social spending. We expect support for VAT to be lower under Neighbor conditions under which citizens are less likely to benefit, especially when they are told that neighboring countries have already implemented taxes. Five dependent variables are: support for VAT, support for taxes, preference between tax imposition or subsidy cuts, economic outlook, and risk assessment.

Treatment 1 (nation-deficit effect): The VAT would be a 5% tax on all goods and services. But, proponents say it will raise billions of dinars necessary to reduce Kuwait's government budget deficit. Treatment 2 (nation-social effect): The VAT would be a 5% tax on all goods and services. But, proponents say it will raise billions of dinars necessary for the government to be able to raise subsidies, healthcare, education, and infrastructure for the Kuwaiti people and our children. Treatment 3 (neighbor-emulation/diffusion effect): The VAT would be a 5/% tax on all goods and services. But, proponents say it has raised billions for governments in more than 140 countries including Saudi Arabia, UAE and Bahrain. Treatment 4 (neighbor-competition/security effect): The VAT would be a 5% tax on all goods and services. But, proponents say that it has raised billions for governments in Saudi Arabia and UAE to build world-class military

attributes.title: Improving Public Works Distribution and Procurement in the Philippines

q1.value: Improving Public Works Distribution and Procurement in the Philippines

q2.value: Eitan Paul | Ronald U. Mendoza | Nico Ravanilla | Allen Hicken

q5.value: We are grateful for the research and project assistance of Ivyrose Baysic, Katherine Peralta, and Jerome Cruz.

q8.value: Registration prior to assignment of treatment

q15.value: We will conduct a randomized controlled trial in the Philippines to evaluate the causal effects of a social accountability initiative on the accountability and transparency of public works provision. Using government data, we observe patterns of inefficiency in the distribution and procurement of public works, favoring projects that allow politicians to extract greater illicit rents, municipalities governed by the same political dynasty as the member of the House of Representatives, and private contractors that are connected to incumbent politicians. We will provide a large coalition of civil society organizations in the Philippines with measures of district-level inefficiencies in public works provision. In half of all 238 congressional districts randomly assigned to treatment, our civil society partner will conduct advocacy targeted at members of the House of Representatives.

q16.value: 1a. Treated members of the House of Representatives will adjust provision of public works projects to alleviate imbalance between “vertical” and “horizontal” projects and reduce disproportionate distribution favoring municipalities with aligned mayors compared to Control. 1b. Only members of the House of Representatives who received reward incentives in T2 will reduce disproportionate distribution favoring municipalities with aligned mayors compared to Control. 2a. DPWH budget itemization will improve in treated districts compared to Control. 2b. DPWH budget itemization will improve only in T2 (Reward) districts compared to Control. 2c. No average effect on itemization. Substitution effect: In districts where representatives improved balance of selected public works projects, itemization may worsen as means of compensating for rents lost to more balanced public goods provision). 3a. The proportion of high-rated firms winning contracts will be higher in treated districts compared to Control. 3b. The proportion of high-rated firms bidding on and winning contracts will only be higher in T2 (reward) districts compared to Control. 4a. Treated legislators will be more likely to respond to and fulfill Sangguniang Kabataan requests compared to Control legislators. 4b. Only T2 (reward) legislators will be more likely to respond to and fulfill SK requests. 4c. Treated legislators will only be more likely to respond to and fulfill SK requests from barangays that supported them in the 2016 election. 5a. Treated legislators will be more likely to communicate with DEOs to engage in procurement oversight than Control legislators. 5b. Only T2 (reward) legislators will be more likely to communicate with DEOs to engage in procurement oversight. 6. The quality of public works projects as assessed by the CPES will improve in treated districts compared to control. 7. Treated legislators who respond positively to the treatment will perform better in the 2019 midterm elections. 8. There will be a reversion to the mean in Outcomes 1 – 4 following the 2019 election (suggesting improvements in legislators’ behavior was driven, at least in part, by concerns about the upcoming election).

q17.value: This study is a randomized controlled trial to test the causal effects of civil society advocacy targeted at legislative offices on the aforementioned outcomes related to the accountability and transparency of public works provision. We will estimate and report intent-to-treat (ITT) and complier average causal effect (CACE), and conditional average treatment effect (CATE). For all administrative data outcomes (all outcomes except Outcomes 3 and 6), we will control for baseline levels. We will use a one-tailed p-value with level α=0.05 for hypotheses in which we have made a specific prediction for the sign of the hypothesized effect (all hypotheses except H2 and for heterogeneous treatment effect by gender). We will run and report the results of two models: 1) T1 + T2 vs. Control, and 2) T1 vs. T2 vs. C.

q19.value: Total units of randomization (including control): 173; Total units of treatment (including control): 228

q23.value: Our study was determined to have IRB Not Regulated Status by the University of Michigan because our research uses publicly available datasets, is on organizations (congressional offices), and will not collect private information about individuals.

q27.value: The treatment will be delivered by RAs from Ateneo de Manila University as representatives of the Ateneo School of Government and the Caucus of Development NGO Networks (CODE-NGO).

attributes.title: Kerosene Survey: Understanding the Preferences of Off-Grid Households in India

q1.value: Kerosene Survey: Understanding the Preferences of Off-Grid Households in India

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: This is a pre-analysis plan that examines kerosene use in rural India. Specifi cally, we conduct a conjoint experiment to determine the factors that will incentivize o-grid households to move away from kerosene and toward a grid or solar connection. The use of kerosene is known to have signi ficant negative effects on households. It is associated with high particulate matter indoors (Lam et al., 2012) and there is also some evidence to suggest that kerosene lamps are more dangerous than other devices that generate indoor smoke (Bates et al., 2013). The use of kerosene lamps can increase the levels of indoor air pollution which, in turn, can increase the risk of disease (Lam et al., 2012). Despite these negative outcomes, kerosene use is very common in India, especially in rural areas. A partial reason revolves around the significant level of subsidies that the Indian government provides to the purchase of kerosene through the public distribution system. There have been some attempts to determine what would wean households away from kerosene use. For example, Barron and Torero (2017) show that grid electrifi cation signi ficantly reduces indoor air pollution. While the connection to the grid is ideal there are a signi ficant number of rural Indian households that do not use grid electri fication. For such populations, off-grid solutions in the form of solar lanterns can also assist in reducing kerosene use (Aklin et al., 2017) and lower indoor air pollution. To determine the factors that have the potential to wean rural households away from kerosene, we focus on four key facets in this study. First, we include information on the hours of electricity supply. This is important since both grid and solar home systems do not always constitute a continuous electricity source. Second, we provide information on the cost of the connection fee. Both grid and solar home systems have associated start-up fees, and this cost can become a signi ficant barrier to adoption. Third, we include information on monthly fees. As with the connection fee, both grid and solar home systems have monthly bills that the household will have to bear as part of their total expenditure. Lastly, we include information on the appliances that can be used with the sources. In addition to the provision of light, the appliances that can run on an electricity source is an important factor in adopting a grid or solar option.

q16.value: We want to examine the effect of each of the connection profi le arms in the conjoint experiment on the preference and the likelihood of adoption. We expect households to prefer a higher number of hours of electricity per day, lower associated costs whether in terms of a connection fee or monthly fee, as well as the ability to run more appliances with an electricity source. Similarly, we expect households to be more likely adopt a connection that oers them higher number of hours of electricty per day, lower associated costs and the ability to run more appliances. Speci fically, the hypotheses we test are: H1a: Higher hours of electricity per day should increase the likelihood of preference of solar home system/grid. H2a: Lower connection fees should increase the likelihood of preference of solar home system/grid. H3a: Lower monthly fees should increase the likelihood of preference of solar home system/grid. H4a: More appliances should increase the likelihood of preference of solar home system/grid. Similarly, we can test hypotheses about the likelihood of adoption for each of the connection profi le arms. H1b: Higher hours of electricity per day should increase the likelihood of adoption of solar home system/grid. H2b: Lower connection fees should increase the likelihood of adoption of solar home system/grid. H3b: Lower monthly fees should increase the likelihood of adoption of solar home system/grid. H4b: More appliances should increase the likelihood of adoption of solar home system/grid.

q17.value: As part of the survey, we administer a conjoint experiment to every respondent. In each pro file set, we present the households with two options: grid and solar home system. The pro files consist of a picture of the grid/SHS, the average hours of electricity per day, one-time connection fee, monthly fee and the appliances that can be run with this option. With the exception of the picture, each of the profi le arms are randomized. The average electricity per day is chosen from 6,12,18 and 24 hrs; the connection fee is chosen from Rs.50, Rs.200 and Rs.300; the monthly fee is chosen from Rs.50, Rs.250 and Rs.500; and the appliances are chosen from fan, television or both. Each respondent is shown four different profi le sets with randomly chosen entries for the arms. The template used to present information for the conjoint experiment is included in the Supplementary Appendix.

attributes.title: Does Participation in Group Decision-Making Increase Investment in Public Goods?

q1.value: Does Participation in Group Decision-Making Increase Investment in Public Goods?

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: Please see attached Pre-Analysis Plan for a full discussion of the study rationale. Here I provide a summary: Stakeholder participation in decision-making is widely encouraged in international development policy, management and research. Instances of “participatory development” (understood as involvement in decision-making of those people meant to benefit from development aid interventions) can be found all over the world. The World Bank alone has invested billions of dollars in the implementation of community-driven development, which emphasizes the participation of beneficiaries in decision-making around development projects (Mansuri & Rao, 2004), and public participation in decision-making is formally encouraged in Kenya’s national constitution. While there are normative reasons to encourage more inclusive decision-making processes, costly and time-intensive group decision-making processes are often justified on the grounds that they may also improve outcomes. One hypothesized effect of deliberative decision-making is that participants are more likely to value outcomes of the decision-making, and thereby more likely to invest in, maintain or comply with those outcomes. The idea that participation in decision-making processes may change people’s beliefs, preferences and behaviors has a long history in political theory (Mansbridge, 1999). Deliberative discussion, in particular, is believed to be more transformative than a mere aggregation of individual preferences. According to democratic theorists, deliberation involves “reason-based decision-making,” in which participants try to persuade each other of a course of action using reasons that appeal to others, such as fairness, group-mindedness or logic regarding effectiveness (Fung & Wright, 2003). This idea has taken root in public policy research as well, where stakeholder participation in decision-making has been widely lauded as a method for improving outcomes in environmental management (Koontz & Thomas, 2006; Reed, 2008), international development (Mansuri & Rao, 2004, 2012), democratic governance (Fung & Wright, 2001), and sustainability science (Mielke et al., 2016), among other areas. Despite the widespread interest, many have observed that the empirical evidence in support of participatory decision-making remains weak (Bäckstrand, Khan, Kronsell & Lövbrand, 2010; Duit & Hall, 2014, Koontz & Thomas, 2006; Birnbaum, 2016). There is very little experimental work on the idea that group decision-making can improve public good contributions.

q16.value: Please see attached Pre-Analysis Plan for full hypotheses and quantities of interest. Here I provide a summary: The main hypothesis is that participation in group decision-making will increase investment in a public good (measured by number of tasks completed in an effort task that earns money for a group fund). Secondary (exploratory) hypotheses are that participation in group decision-making will also influence: perceptions of fairness (survey question), agreement with outcomes (survey question), preference matching (comparing survey question to group decision outcome), preference change (comparing survey question before and after treatment), collective efficacy (guess as to how well team will perform), complementary investment (decision in a follow-up one-shot public good game), and willingness to participate again (survey question).

q17.value: Please see attached Pre-Analysis Plan for full discussion of methods. Here I provide a summary: Study participants will be randomly assigned to one of 4 treatment groups or a control, and then assigned to teams of 5 people. The four treatment groups engage in a group decision-making process, while the control does not. The treatment groups vary as to how the decision is made (either majority rule or deliberative consensus and either secret ballot or public show of hands voting). The decision-making process determines an effort task that the team will engage in to earn money as a team, mimicking a public good experiment. I will then examine whether the treatment assignment influenced effort in the task (contribution to the public good). I will also use survey questions to get at some secondary hypotheses related to potential intermediate outcomes.
